document_data.mainbody: '''Velsharoon''' ({{Pronounce|VEL|shah|roon|refs=}}), also known as '''Mellifleur''',<ref group="note">Mellifleur, later known as, was a multi-[[Crystal sphere|sphere]] [[lesser deity]] of [[lich]]es first described in ''[[Monster Mythology]]''. Velsharoon took his name as an alias, but their relationship is unclear, as they shared some similarities but also differed in many details. was the [[Faerûnian pantheon|Faerunian]] [[demigod]] of [[necromancy]], the patron of [[lich]]es and those that explored [[undeath]]. Arrogant and obsessed, the '''Archmage of Necromancy''' continued his experiments on the living and the dead as a god, paying no heed to the lesser lives lost in the name of his research and encouraging his disciples to do the same.{{cite book/Magic of Faerûn|7-8}}

Description.Manifestations: Velsharoon's favored manifestation was a burning skull, wreathed in red, pale blue or blue-green flames. He was fond of using various gemstones to denote his favor or presence of hues including black, purple, maroon, rust-red, gray, and a bright and unnatural green reminiscent of [[green slime]]s. The sudden appearance of a [[bloodrose]] was said to herald him.

document_data.Personality: As a god, Velsharoon was canny, yet extremely vain and selfish, concerned overmuch with revenge and experimenting on both living and dead. This was not a great change from the mortal he was.
document_data.Possessions: In his humanoid form, Velsharoon wielded the ''[[Skull Staff of the Necromancer]]''.
document_data.Divine Realm: Velsharoon had his [[divine realm]] called [[Death's Embrace]] on [[Mungoth]], the third mount of [[Gehenna]] in the [[Great Wheel cosmology]]. In the [[World Tree cosmology]] it lay on the magical plane of [[Dweomerheart]], far underground beneath [[Azuth (realm)|Azuth]] and [[The Eye]]. In appearance a moldy tomb, Death's Embrace was a repository of all necromantic knowledge.<ref>
document_data.Rumors:
His influence was felt in the {{yearlink|1090}}, in the place that would later become the [[Battle of Bones]], where a floating, flame-wreathed skull was seen during the last skirmish in the war, though he wouldn't become a divinity until later. Whether the symbol foretold his ascension or was adopted upon his embrace was not known.{{cite book/Elminster's Ecologies Appendix I/The Battle of Bones|14}}

The Simbul was said to have sacrificed herself to destroy the god's corpse in the [[Astral Plane]].{{cite book/Forgotten Realms Player's Guide|77}}
document_data.Trivia: There was a ring belonging to Empress [[Shoon V]] of the late 3{{rd}} century [[DR]] known as the ''[[Dual Ring of Velsharoon's Bindings]]''.{{cite book/Calimport|91}} His relationship to the ring is unknown.<ref group="note">Apart from the name, it is unknown how Velsharoon is linked to the ring and who or what is under bindings. It is possible the ring was associated with Velsharoon after Shoon V's ownership of it.
